comment.author: 19909418@N05
comment._content: I learned to skate on these friese doorlopers in the winter of 1950-51. The were light, and low enough to the surface of the ice for the young skater not to wobble, lose balance and fall. I noticed that as people had more disposible money, in the 70s, young children were given relatively expensive kunstschaatsen, the kind used in figure-skating competitions, with blades permanently attached to white leather boots. Although they looked good, I always thought that it was much more difficult for younger children to learn how to skate well (glide smoothly with long strokes) in those.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called artland, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 28275115@N03
comment._content:
prachtige opname, roept herinneringen op

de leren riempjes waren een crime, gingen steeds los

comment.author: 8798197@N04
comment._content: i learned to skate on doorlopers too, and these were given to me in the 1970s by my parents. From my grandmother i learned a failsafe way to tie them so that they didn't get loose.

comment.author: 98338006@N00
comment._content:
'I noticed that as people had more disposible money, in the 70s, young children were given relatively expensive kunstschaatsen, the kind used in figure-skating competitions, with blades permanently attached to white leather boots.'

that's probably the reason I never really learned to skate ;-)
Another thing on 'kunstschaatsen': at the time, it was still not done for women  to skate on the fast skates men were using..
